Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Large-Scale Structures in Turbulent Dynamo Experiments with Liquid-Metal Suspensions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Brown
1255541

The turbulent dynamo process is the generation of a magnetic field from the turbulent flow of a conducting fluid; which occurs for example in the Earth's core. An understanding of how turbulent flow structures generate the magnetic field is a central challenge in dynamo research. However, only one experiment has been able to produce a turbulent dynamo because of the extreme material properties and scale required; even in that case the fluid flows that generate the magnetic field have not yet been measured, and the fluid flows cannot be directly simulated in the strongly turbulent regime. The goals of this research plan are to use materials design to develop a revolutionary approach to magnetohydrodynamic experiments, and combine experiments and low-dimensional modeling to understand how fluid flow structures interact to generate magnetic fields in dynamos. The extreme parameter regime required for generating a turbulent dynamo in the laboratory will be reached by designing materials consisting of magnetic particles suspended in a liquid metal, i.e. micron-sized iron particles suspended in liquid gallium and its alloys. Such a fluid will have a high enough conductivity and magnetic susceptibility to build the universe's smallest turbulent dynamo (10 cm). The first simultaneous measurements of fluid flow and magnetic field in a turbulent dynamo will be made to connect their dynamics with an array of temperature and magnetic field probes at several locations around the apparatus. Turbulent flow structures can be reconstructed from such measurements, and modeled with low-dimensional models consisting of stochastic ordinary differential equations. These experimental and modeling techniques will be combined to understand how turbulent flow structures interact to produce magnetic fields.

Intellectual merit: This materials design is a novel approach to dynamos that would transform the field by opening up experimental research to more laboratories -- experiments could be scaled down and the need for large facilities to handle liquid sodium in traditional dynamo experiments would be eliminated. The tunable material properties of suspensions will allow for a direct comparison with simulations in the same parameter regime which has not been possible with traditional dynamo experiments. The first simultaneous measurements of turbulent flow structures and magnetic fields in an experimental dynamo will allow development and testing of models for how turbulent flow structures generate a magnetic field. The low-dimensional modeling techniques have the potential to become a new paradigm for simple understanding and quantitative predictions of different dynamical behaviors of large-scale structures in a wide variety of turbulent flows.

Broader impacts: Materials design will result in the development and characterization of fluids with useful tunable properties including high conductivity and a strong magnetic response; possible applications include magnetorheological brakes with reduced heat dissipation, and fluid power transformers with no moving solid parts. Astronomical dynamos such as the Earth and Sun have complicated dynamics that are not well-understood. Solar flares can interfere with long-wave radio communications and produce radiation hazards to spacecraft. Earth's magnetic field protects against dangerous radiation from the Sun. Modeling of magnetic dynamos may lead to better understanding of their dynamical behavior, which could have a positive impact on aerospace engineering. An integrated scientific research education program for undergraduates will be developed at UC Merced, a minority-serving research institution. This includes coordination of the lower division and upper division laboratory courses, and senior theses, with a focus on the scientific method and data analysis. These educational components will be evaluated according to a rubric for laboratory reports, theses, and presentations in line the physics program's learning objectives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we produced and characterized a relatively new class of materials consisting of magnetic particles suspended in liquid metals.  These materials flow like liquids, respond to magnetic fields like paramagnetic materials, and are highly conductive.   The magnetic response is fast and reversible, allowing for easy control.  We found magnetic susceptibilities of up to 4, which is not as strong as most ferromagnets, but several orders of magnitude larger than the magnetic response of liquids.  This is large enough to expect to be able to observe a fluid dynamo (similar to the one in Earth’s core that generates Earth’s magnetic field) in a system as small as 20 cm.  We found several combinations of liquid metals and magnetic particles that have these features, and developed and reported a process that makes these materials easy to produce in most wet laboratories.  By making this phenomena more accessible, we hope to expand opportunities to study such phenomena and make use of this class of materials.    These material properties may prove useful for other new applications such as mechanical-electrical power transformers without solid friction, or to provide better materials for existing applications, such as magnetorheological dampers.
    When comparing to models, we found that the magnetic susceptibility of spherical particles or forcibly-aligned rod shaped particles could be described by an existing model.  However, non-spherical particles randomly arrange in suspensions, and did not achieve the higher susceptibilities predicted because of their tendency to align randomly in suspensions,  which means that particle alignment should be taken into account in future models of the magnetic susceptibility of suspensions for real suspensions of non-spherical particles.

In another line of research,  we investigated the dynamics of large-scale circulations (LSCs) in turbulence.   These LSCs are organized coherent structures that survive for long periods of time, and tend to be large enough to fill the space they are in.  An example of these LSCs in nature are convection rolls in the atmosphere, which control many aspects of weather and climate.   LSCs in the Earth’s core likely control the dynamics of Earth’s magnetic field, which changes over time and is hypothesized to be responsible for mass extinction events in the past when the magnetic field switches direction.  We have been testing and developing a model that can  predict  the dynamics of these LSCs.  Traditional approaches to modeling large-scale turbulent flows involve equations that are too difficult to solve for many of these problems, even using supercomputers.  We developed a statistical model that takes advantage of the organized structure of LSCs to make the equations easier to solve.  While turbulence is by its nature too sensitive to external forces to make predictions of specific events very far into the future with any model, this type of stochastic model — once fully developed — can make statistical predictions of statistics.   One example of a statistical prediction would be how the average number of hurricanes we expect to see per year in a region would change as a result of climate change, which would be very valuable for land use planning and insurers.
    We have demonstrated that the model successfully predicted 2 new dynamical modes of LSCs in a new geometry (e.g. a cube) that did not exist in previously studied geometries: specifically a switching of the LSC orientation from being aligned with one diagonal of the cube to another, and oscillations of the LSC orientation around individual corners.  These observations  confirm the ability of the model to make predictions of LSC dynamics for different flow geometries.   The model is formulated in such a way that it can make predictions for arbitrary boundary cross-section shapes, so while we only tested the model predictions in a cubic cell, the agreement suggests that predictions would also work for other boundary shapes or topographies as well.  We also performed experiments in a wider cell with 2 neighboring LSCs that couple to each other, which often occurs in nature.  By comparing the behavior of each LSC to the behavior of a single LSC, we can obtain terms for the interaction between neighboring LSCs.    This geometry dependence, and the coupling terms between neighboring LSCs are two of the main aspects of natural convective flows that have not been previously modeled, so these results bring a significantly closer to modeling such phenomena.
